entry.title: a 4 December 1915 agreement (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a 4 December 1915 agreement by French prime minister Aristide Briand (pictured) with a British proposal to evacuate the Salonika front almost led to the collapse of his government?

entry.title: Julian Moynahan (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a reviewer wrote of Julian Moynahan that, although "disguised as an English professor at Rutgers", he was in fact "a nonstop Irish-American storyteller"?

entry.title: Japanese tree frog (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the calling patterns of the Japanese tree frog have been used in wireless network design, furthering an area of science known as swarm intelligence?

entry.title: Katharina Cibulka (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Katharina Cibulka has created monumental feminist messages in cross-stitch that cover scaffolding at construction sites?

entry.title: Gegrüßet seist du, Königin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that "Gegrüßet seist du, Königin", a German version of the Latin hymn "Salve Regina", was taken to the U.S. by emigrants and became popular in the U.S. in the film Sister Act?

entry.title: DreamBooth (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that while DreamBooth can be used by anyone to fine-tune image generation AI models, the cost barrier to entry is quite high for hobbyist users?

entry.title: Ye Dehui (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Chinese writer Ye Dehui was executed after he called members of the Chinese Communist Party "beasts" and "half-breeds"?

entry.title: a KAVE in New Mexico (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a Royal Air Force officer built a KAVE in New Mexico?
